reasoning: The critique targets a potentially important assumption behind rapid software progress—namely that additional/smarter cognitive labor translates into substantially faster algorithmic discovery—by arguing that the effective difficulty of finding improvements may grow (roughly) exponentially, creating a non-compute bottleneck. This is somewhat central to the broader SIE optimism, but it is not very central to the post’s specific claim that *compute* bottlenecks likely won’t bind early; the post already discusses diminishing returns/"low-hanging fruit" and focuses on substitutability between compute and cognition. The argument offered is largely a high-level assertion (rugged landscape, entropy, exponential search) without justification, operationalization, or engagement with the post’s points (e.g., shifting to less compute-intensive routes, changing the production process, multiple avenues of progress). As a result it weakly undermines the position. Its factual content is mixed: it’s plausible that search gets harder and landscapes are rugged, but claims like “search space grows exponentially” and “intelligence only gives linear/poly scaling” are unsupported and may be false in relevant regimes. The critique is understandable but somewhat vague about mechanisms and why this wouldn’t already be captured by a low effective rho / diminishing returns. Little dead weight and it sticks to a single point.
title: Exponential search space growth may bottleneck progress despite favorable hardware scaling
